etymologies: early 20th century (in sense ‘inflate a balloon or tyre again’): from re-‘again’, on the pattern of inflate, deflate. The modern sense dates from the 1930s

definitions: expand the level of output of (an economy) by government stimulus, using either fiscal or monetary policy

examples.text: Western states pressured Schmidt to reflate the West German economy faster
countries are often unwilling to reflate on their own

shortDefinitions: expand level of output of economy by government stimulus
